thread.title: Asian Stocks Gain, Paring July Loss, Ahead of China Factory Data
thread.title_full: Asian Stocks Gain, Paring July Loss, Ahead of China Factory Data - Bloomberg Business

author: Adam Haigh
title: Asian Stocks Gain, Paring July Loss, Ahead of China Factory Data
text:
Asian stocks rose as investors weighed earnings reports in Japan ahead of manufacturing data that may provide a clue to the strength of China’s economic growth.
The MSCI Asia Pacific Index gained 0.2 percent to 141.08 as of 9:07 a.m. in Tokyo. The gauge is on course to decline 0.9 percent this week and 3.5 percent in July, which would be its worst monthly drop this year. China discloses July factory output on Saturday, after a private report showed manufacturing unexpectedly fell to a 15-month low in the month. Today is the busiest day of Japan’s earnings season, with more than 310 Topix companies scheduled to post results.
“The risk for today’s trade is not in the intraday data or individual earnings -- it’s investors positioning themselves for China’s official manufacturing data,” said Evan Lucas, a Melbourne-based markets strategist at IG Ltd. We may “see negative trading in the afternoon as investors close out positions to mitigate that possible risk” arising from the weekend’s manufacturing report.
Japan’s Topix index gained 0.2 percent. Sony Corp. profit tripled in the first quarter as a renewed focus on sensor chips and video games begins to pay off for an electronics maker that posted losses in six of the past seven years. The Nikkei 225 Stock Average slid 0.1 percent, dragged down by its heaviest-weighted companies, Fast Retailing Co. and Fanuc Corp.
Australia’s S&P/ASX 200 Index added 0.1 percent. South Korea’s Kospi index rose 0.4 percent and New Zealand’s NZX 50 Index added 0.1 percent.
Futures on Hong Kong’s Hang Seng Index and contracts on the Hang Seng China Enterprises Index both rose 0.1 percent. FTSE China A50 Index futures added 0.8 percent in Singapore.
China-Linked ETF The biggest U.S.-traded exchange-traded fund tracking Chinese equities slid 3 percent Thursday after the Shanghai Composite Index fell for the fourth time in five days. The index is down 14 percent this month, the most since June 2013 as China’s regulators grappled to arrest the rout in a market that was one of the world’s best performing earlier this year.
E-mini futures on the Standard & Poor’s 500 Index slid 0.1 percent. The underlying gauge on Thursday was little changed.
U.S. gross domestic product rose at a 2.3 percent annualized rate, the Commerce Department said Thursday, after a previously reported contraction for the first quarter was replaced with a 0.6 percent gain. The median forecast of 80 economists surveyed by Bloomberg called for a 2.5 percent advance for the second three months of the year.
